title: Millville-Ocean City football preview
text:
Millville-Ocean City football preview JOSH FRIEDMAN, @JFriedman57 5 p.m. EDT October 15, 2015 Millville's Dajour Brown (left) carries the ball as Ocean City's Christian Baumgardner chases him during a game last season. (Photo: File photo) 14 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Key Matchups Millville LB Clayton Scott (5-feet, 7-inches, 167 pounds) vs. Ocean City quarterback Andrew Donohue (6-2, 180). The Red Raiders run a spread offense, looking to get the ball to their playmakers in space. Donohue threw for 202 yards in a 13-7 setback to Vineland in Week 2, and has the ability to get his team down the field quickly. Scott is Millville’s top pass rusher. If he can disrupt Donohue’s rhythm, the Thunderbolts will have a good chance at pulling out the win. Millville LB Zack Douglas (6-0, 206) vs. Ocean City RB Dan Henderson (5-8, 192). If the Thunderbolts slow down Ocean City’s aerial attack, the Red Raiders will turn to Henderson to get the offense moving. Henderson rushed for 98 yards against Vineland earlier this year, and is the team’s steadiest producer on the ground. Douglas leads Millville in tackles (48) and tackles for loss (15). He’ll be keying on Henderson all game. Millville C Stephen Haynes (6-1, 286) vs. Ocean City DT Christian Baumgardner (6-5, 235). The Thunderbolts, like the Red Raiders, have excelled through the air. Quarterback Will Polhamus has completed an area-best 42 passes this season and he’ll look to continue that success against Ocean City. To do that, he’ll need to stay upright, and that means keeping Baumgardner, a University of Virginia recruit, out of the backfield. Haynes will have a key role in slowing him down. 
Keys to the Game Millville needs to start fast. Ocean City pulled out its first victory of the season last week, topping Egg Harbor Township 19-7. The Red Raiders scored the first 19 points of the game - all in the first half. The Thunderbolts have averaged fewer than 15 points per game this year (14.75). Millville has a lot of potential on offense, but is still trying to put together a complete game. If the Thunderbolts fall behind early, it’ll make earning a victory far more difficult. Millville must maintain balance on offense. The Thunderbolts finally got their ground game going in their win over Absegami last week, rushing for a season-best 180 yards. If Millville can continue that success running the ball, Polhamus will have a lot more opportunities to air it out down the field. Millville has to cut down on turnovers. The Thunderbolts scored a season-high 22 points against Absegami, but they could’ve had a lot more had they not given the ball away four times (three interceptions, lost fumble). Ocean City proved it was capable of pulling off an upset with its win over EHT. Millville can’t afford to let the Red Raiders hang around. 
Prediction 
Millville 20, Ocean City 6 
— Josh Friedman 
Millville (2-2) at Ocean City (1-4) 
When: Friday, 7 p.m. 
Where: Carey Stadium, 501 Atlantic Ave., Ocean City 
Coaches: Millville: Dennis Thomas (1st season, 2-2); Ocean City: Kevin Smith (5th season, 13-32). 
On the air: Live on TV SNJ channel 22 or www.snjtoday.com 
All-time series: Millville leads 27-23-2. 
Last meeting: Millville 49, Ocean City 10, 2014. Ryquell Armstead rushed for 151 yards and scored four touchdowns to lead the Thunderbolts to victory. Dajour Brown recorded his varsity touchdown on a 29-yard run, and Zack Douglas made his first TD reception, hauling in a 30-yard pass from quarterback Will Polhamus. Chris Harris caught a 75-yard touchdown pass from Polhamus as well. 
Key stats: 6 — First-quarter points scored by Millville this season. The Thunderbolts haven’t scored in the opening quarter since Brown’s 47-yard touchdown reception from Polhamus in the season-opener against Mainland. 22 — Points scored by Millville in last week’s victory over Absegami, a season high. The Thunderbolts had scored a total of 27 points in their first three games of the year. Minus-21 — Rushing yards for Absegami in Millville’s win last week. 10 — Penalties by the Thunderbolts in their victory over the Braves. Millville had just five penalties in each of their first three games this year. 180 — Rushing yards by the Thunderbolts’ Clayton Scott against Absegami. Millville had 59 yards on the ground combined in their first three contests this year. 2008 — The last year the Thunderbolts didn’t have at least three wins through five weeks. That was Millville’s first season under previous coach Jason Durham. 
— Josh Friedman 14 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://vineland.dj/1LvUz4H TOP VIDEOS
